LESSONS LEARNED

They say the party ended in 2000, and it was time to wake up! So tonight, I’m going to celebrate like it’s 1999!

The NASDAQ hit a high of 5,048 in March 2000 but then dropped to 3,321 by April. It kept falling until it hit 1,114 in October 2002. People started to think that the market crash was a sign that the tech hype of the '90s was over. What was once seen as a time of great hope turned into a time of greed, and everyone agreed that it was definitely over.

After that, people learned to think about the future as uncertain. Anyone with big plans that took years instead of just a few months was seen as extreme. Instead of focusing on technology, people started to believe in globalization as the new hope. Since the shift from physical stores to online shopping didn’t work out as expected, investors went back to real estate and global markets. This led to another bubble, this time in housing.
